awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Samuel Punshon-Smith is "Regularization by noise in kinetic equations." The host institution for the fellowship is Brown University, and the sponsoring scientist is Govind Menon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The purpose of NSF Postdoctoral Grant DMS 1803481 was primarily to study and use the regularization properties of noise on various challenging problems in kinetic theory and related problems in fluid mechanics.

Intellectual Merit

During the tenure of this grant the PI primarily focused on the study of chaos and mixing in fluid mechanics with random velocity fields, a notoriously challenging problem, where the addition of noise can regularize things significantly. In a series of papers, the PI, along with collaborators Jacob Bedrossian and Alex Blumenthal, sought to understand the chaotic mixing properties of the Lagrangian flow map and related scalar transport properties associated to a class of continuous-in-time stochastic velocity fields, including, most notably, the stochastic Navier-Stokes equations in 2d (as well as 3d hyperviscous Navier-Stokes and Stokes), which are the fundamental equations governing the motion of a fluid. Using the randomness of the velocity, the PI first proved that motion of particles in such a fluid is always chaotic, a property observed by physicists and termed "Lagrangian chaos", yet not rigorously proved until this work. In a subsequent work, the PI showed that this property implies a very strong mixing effect in the distribution of particles. In essence, the PI showed that a sufficiently randomly forced fluid will always send a blob of black paint in a white background to a uniform grey exponentially fast (namely no eddies trap paint forever). This work provided some of the first examples of time and space continuous universal mixers for scalar advection. Continuing in this direction, the PI and collaborators then studied the effect of diffusion on this mixing property. The PI proved that the mixing happens uniformly in the strength of the diffusivity, producing the first known examples of velocity fields with such an effect, and showing that it is in a sense "typical" for most suitably generic fluid motions. Finally, the PI used this very strong property of the fluid motion to give the first rigorous proof of a fundamental law in passive scalar turbulence, known as "Batchelor's law", which describes how a tracer distributes itself at different scales in a fluid.

In addition to the above work on chaos and mixing, the PI also pursued the problem of proving that the motion velocity of a randomly forcing fluid is chaotic, termed "Eulerian chaos" to distinguish it from chaos of the particles. With the same collaborators, the PI developed a general method for bounding Lyapunov exponents from below using hypoelliptic regularity theory for a certain stationary measure that tracks tangent directions. As a result the PI gave a first proof of chaos for the randomly forced Lorenz 96 model, often considered a prototype for chaotic motion. Later the PI developed novel tools using computational algebraic geometry to extend the above analysis to Galerkin truncations of the 2d stochastic Navier-Stokes equations (i.e. numerical approximations of the equations of 2d fluid mechanics). The methods developed here are very general and have broad applicability to many numerical approximations of chaotic partial differential equations.

Broader Impacts

The research described above is motivated by the study of turbulence and mixing in fluids. Such problems are relevant in applications beyond mathematics. The results on Lagrangian chaos, uniform mixing and Batchelor's law made significant advances towards understanding the key mechanism behind mixing in a variety of fluid models. Problems related to mixing have fundamental importance in engineering, oceanography, and chemical engineering, particularly microfluidic mixing. The recent work on proving positive Lyapunov exponents for Galerkin-Navier-Stokes has created a new connection between fluid mechanics and computational algebraic geometry. During the duration of the grant the PI gave, in total, 15 seminar talks and 14 talks at conferences/workshops, including an invited talk at the international congress on mathematical Physics. The PI also produced 9 publications/preprints with 7 being accepted in high ranking and high impact journals. The PI was also a co-organizer of the PDE seminar at Brown. During the grant, the PI gave a graduate topics course on stochastic PDEs aimed at training graduate students in the area. The PI wrote comprehensive notes on the subject that are publicly available on their website.
